openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Canada is classified as a highly developed mixed economy, characterized by a combination of private and public enterprise.
• As of 2024, Canada ranks as the ninth-largest economy in the world based on nominal GDP, which is approximately US$2.117 trillion.
• Canada is one of the world's largest trading nations, with a highly globalized economy that facilitates extensive international commerce.
• In 2021, Canada's total trade in goods and services reached US$2.016 trillion, reflecting significant economic activity.
• Canadian exports in 2021 totaled over US$637 billion, while imports were valued at over US$631 billion, indicating a substantial trade volume.
• Approximately US$391 billion of Canada's imported goods in 2021 originated from the United States, highlighting the close economic ties between the two countries.
• In 2018, Canada experienced a trade deficit in goods of US$22 billion and a trade deficit in services of US$25 billion, illustrating trade imbalances.
• The Toronto Stock Exchange (TSX) is the tenth-largest stock exchange globally by market capitalization, listing over 1,500 companies with a combined market value exceeding US$3 trillion.
• Canada has a robust cooperative banking sector, with the highest per-capita membership in credit unions worldwide, emphasizing community-based financial services.
• The country ranks 12th in the 2023 Corruption Perceptions Index, and is widely regarded as among the least corrupt nations globally.
• Canada ranks 14th in the 2019 Global Competitiveness Report and 15th in the 2022 Global Innovation Index, indicating a strong position in global economic competitiveness and innovation.
• The Canadian economy ranks above most Western nations on The Heritage Foundation's Index of Economic Freedom, reflecting a relatively open and free-market environment.
• Canada maintains a relatively low level of income disparity, with the average household disposable income per capita being "well above" the OECD average.
• The country ranks among the lowest in the OECD for housing affordability and foreign direct investment, suggesting challenges in these areas.
• Canada's social security system is highly efficient and robust, with social expenditures constituting approximately 23.1% of GDP among OECD members.
• Since the early 20th century, Canada's economic structure has shifted from predominantly rural to urbanized and industrial, driven by growth in manufacturing, mining, and services sectors.
• The service industry now employs about 75% of Canada's workforce, reflecting its dominance in the economy.
• Canada has an unusually significant primary sector among developed nations, with forestry and petroleum industries being the most prominent components.
• Many northern towns, where agriculture is limited, rely on nearby mining or timber industries for economic sustenance.
• Canada invests around 1.70% of its GDP in advanced research and development across various economic sectors.
• The country's economic integration with the United States has grown markedly since World War II, facilitated by multiple trade agreements.
• The 1965 Automotive Products Trade Agreement opened Canada's borders to automobile manufacturing trade, fostering industry growth.
• In the 1970s, Canada enacted the National Energy Program (NEP) and established the Foreign Investment Review Agency (FIRA) to address energy independence and foreign ownership concerns.
• The NEP was abolished in the 1980s, and FIRA was renamed Investment in Canada to promote foreign investment.
• The 1988 Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement (FTA) eliminated tariffs between the two nations, boosting bilateral trade.
• NAFTA, established in 1994, expanded the free-trade zone to include Mexico, later replaced by the Canada–United States–Mexico Agreement (CUSMA).
• As of 2023, Canada is a signatory to 15 free trade agreements involving 51 countries, underscoring its commitment to international trade liberalization.
• Canada is one of the few developed nations that are net energy exporters, with Atlantic Canada possessing extensive offshore natural gas deposits.

• Alberta hosts the world's fourth-largest oil reserves, including the vast Athabasca oil sands, which contribute to Canada's 13% of global oil reserves, making it the third or fourth-largest globally.
• Canada is a major global supplier of agricultural products, with the Canadian Prairies being key producers of wheat, canola, and other grains.

• The country is a leading exporter of minerals and metals, including zinc, uranium, gold, nickel, platinum group metals, aluminum, steel, iron ore, coking coal, lead, copper, molybdenum, cobalt, and cadmium.
• Canada's manufacturing sector is concentrated in southern Ontario and Quebec, with automobiles and aeronautics as particularly significant industries.
• The fishing industry also plays a vital role in Canada's economy, contributing to employment and exports.
• The economy of Canada is part of a broader series on Canadian economic history, including topics such as banking history, petroleum history, energy policy, and the Canadian dollar.
• Canada’s economy is divided into three main sectors: primary, secondary, and tertiary.
• The primary sector includes agriculture, energy, petroleum, electricity, mining, fishing, and forestry, reflecting Canada's rich natural resource base.
• The secondary sector primarily involves manufacturing industries such as automotives, which contribute to industrial production.
• The tertiary sector encompasses services such as social programs, transportation, and tourism, which form a significant part of Canada's service-oriented economy.
• Canada's financial system includes a central bank, a well-developed banking sector, and stock exchanges, with companies listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange (TSX).
• Several major Canadian companies are listed on the TSX, representing key industries and economic sectors.
• The Canadian economy varies by province, with notable economic centers in Alberta, Ontario, Quebec, Saskatchewan, among others.
• Major cities contributing to the economy include Montreal, Toronto, and Vancouver, each serving as economic hubs.
• Canada is unique in North America for using a parliamentary system of government, shared with few island nations in the Caribbean, which has influenced its social and political institutions.
• Although closely integrated with the U.S. economy, Canada has developed distinct economic institutions and a mixed economy combining private and public enterprise elements.
• Many aspects of public enterprise, especially welfare programs aimed at addressing social and economic inequalities, were established after World War II ended in 1945.
• Approximately 89% of Canada's land is Crown land, which is owned by the government.
• Canada ranks highly in global economic freedom, reflecting a market-oriented economic system similar to that of the United States.
• As of 2019, Canada has 56 companies listed in the Forbes Global 2000, ranking ninth globally, just behind South Korea and ahead of Saudi Arabia.
• International trade is vital to Canada's economy, especially in natural resources; in 2009, exports from agriculture, energy, forestry, and mining accounted for about 58% of total exports.
• Machinery, equipment, automotive products, and other manufactured goods made up approximately 38% of Canadian exports in 2009.
• In 2009, exports represented about 30% of Canada's GDP.
• The United States is Canada's largest trading partner, accounting for approximately 73% of Canadian exports and 63% of imports as of 2009.
• In 2006, Canada's total exports and imports ranked 8th among all nations.
• About 4% of Canadians are directly employed in primary resource industries, which contribute approximately 6.2% to the GDP.
• Many towns in northern Canada depend economically on nearby mines or timber sources, especially where agriculture is impractical.
• Canada is a leading global producer of natural resources including gold, nickel, uranium, diamonds, lead, and increasingly crude petroleum, which has the second-largest oil reserves in the world.
• Several large Canadian resource companies include Encana, Cameco, Goldcorp, and Barrick Gold.

• The majority of natural resource products are exported mainly to the United States, with secondary and service industries linked to primary industries, such as the pulp and paper sector connected to logging.
• The reliance on natural resources influences regional economic development, leading to diverse economic structures across different regions and contributing to strong regionalism.

• Natural resources' export orientation makes Canada highly integrated into the international economy, but also introduces economic instability, prompting increased government intervention to mitigate social impacts.
• Despite decades of resource extraction, concerns about sustainability persist; discoveries like the large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay exemplify ongoing resource potential.
• The far north remains largely undeveloped due to high costs, technological limitations, and waiting for higher prices or new technologies.
• Environmental concerns have grown, with Canadians increasingly opposed to environmental degradation caused by resource exploitation, influenced by high wages and Aboriginal land claims.

• Many Canadian resource companies are expanding exploration and exploitation activities overseas in regions such as Latin America, Southeast Asia, and Africa, where costs are lower and governments more accommodating.

• The depletion of renewable resources has raised sustainability issues; for example, the cod fishery collapsed in the 1990s after decades of overfishing, and the Pacific salmon industry also suffered significant declines.
• The logging industry has shifted toward more sustainable practices or relocated to other countries following years of activism and environmental concerns.
• Productivity measures are essential indicators of economic performance, serving as key sources of economic growth and competitiveness.

• The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) publishes the _Compendium of Productivity Indicators_ annually, providing a comprehensive overview of productivity levels and growth among member nations.
• The OECD report emphasizes key measurement issues related to productivity assessment.
• It analyzes the role of productivity as the primary driver of economic growth and convergence across economies.
• The report highlights the contributions of three main factors to economic growth: labour, capital, and multi-factor productivity (MFP).
• Multi-factor productivity (MFP) is often interpreted as the contribution to economic growth resulting from factors such as technical innovation and organizational improvements.
• Measures of productivity include gross domestic product (GDP) and total factor productivity (TFP).

• Multifactor productivity (MFP), also known as total factor productivity (TFP), is a long-term trend measure used by the OECD to evaluate an economy’s underlying productive capacity or potential output, which is a key indicator of economic growth prospects and inflationary pressures.

• MFP assesses the residual growth in an economy that cannot be explained by changes in the services of labour, capital, and intermediate outputs, and is often interpreted as the contribution of technological and organizational innovation to economic growth.
• According to the OECD’s annual economic survey of Canada published in June 2012, Canada has experienced weak growth in MFP, which has been declining further since 2002.
• One method to increase MFP growth is by boosting innovation; however, Canada's innovation indicators, such as business R&D expenditure and patenting rates, have been poor.
• Enhancing MFP growth is essential for sustaining rising living standards, particularly in the context of an aging population.
• Since 2010, Canada’s productivity growth has improved, driven almost entirely by above-average multifactor productivity growth.
• Despite recent improvements, Canada's overall productivity still lags behind the upper half of OECD countries, such as the United States.
• Currently, Canada's productivity level is approximately at the OECD median, comparable to that of Australia.
• To further increase productivity, Canada can focus on improving the productivity of capital by enhancing the capital stock to output ratio and capital quality.
• Suggested strategies for improving capital productivity include the liberalization of internal trade barriers, as recommended in the OECD’s latest Canadian economic survey.
• The Bank of Canada is the central bank of Canada, responsible for conducting monetary policy within the country.
• Its primary mandate is to "preserve the value of money by keeping inflation low and stable."
• The overarching goal of the Bank of Canada's monetary policy is to maintain price stability, which supports economic growth and employment.
• The Bank of Canada aims to keep inflation close to a target rate of 2%, with a control range typically between 1% and 3%.
• The institution uses various tools to implement monetary policy, including setting the target for the overnight rate, conducting open market operations, and influencing the money supply.
• The Bank of Canada’s decisions on interest rates directly impact borrowing costs, consumer spending, and investment in the economy.
• The Bank’s monetary policy framework emphasizes transparency and accountability, with regular reports and communications to inform the public and markets.
• The Bank of Canada was established in 1934 and operates independently from the government to ensure objective monetary policy decisions.
• Its operations are guided by the Bank of Canada Act, which outlines its responsibilities and mandates.
• The Bank’s monetary policy decisions are made by the Governing Council, which meets approximately eight times per year.
• The Bank also plays a role in issuing and distributing Canada’s banknotes and maintaining the stability of the financial system.
• The Bank of Canada’s monetary policy actions are aimed at achieving its inflation target while supporting economic stability and confidence in the Canadian dollar.
• The Bank of Canada issues its bank rate announcement through its Monetary Policy Report, which is released eight times annually.
• The Bank of Canada is a federal crown corporation responsible for overseeing Canada's monetary system.
• Since the early 1990s, Canada has adopted an inflation-targeting monetary policy, which has been the cornerstone of its monetary and fiscal policy framework.
• The Bank of Canada sets an inflation target of 2 percent, which is the midpoint of an established inflation range of 1 to 3 percent.
• The inflation-targeting policy aims to keep inflation "low, stable and predictable," thereby fostering confidence in the value of money.
• The policy also seeks to contribute to Canada's sustained economic growth, employment gains, and improved standard of living.
• On January 9, 2019, Bank of Canada Governor Stephen S. Poloz issued a statement summarizing major events since the October 2018 Monetary Policy Report.
• Key events included the "negative economic consequences" of the US-led trade war with China.
• In response to the trade war, global financial markets experienced falling bond yields, more flattened yield curves, and significant re-pricing of stock markets.
• In Canada, low oil prices are expected to negatively impact the country's macroeconomic outlook.
• Canada's housing sector has not been stabilizing as quickly as anticipated, indicating ongoing vulnerabilities in the housing market.

• During John Crow's tenure as Governor of the Bank of Canada from 1987 to 1994, the country experienced a worldwide recession, with the bank rate rising to approximately 14% and unemployment exceeding 11%.

• Inflation-targeting was adopted by most advanced-world central banks after this period; however, in 1991, it was considered innovative, and Canada was an early adopter when the then-Finance Minister Michael Wilson approved the Bank of Canada's first inflation-targeting policy in the 1991 federal budget.
• The initial inflation target was set at 2 percent, with inflation measured by the total consumer price index (CPI).
• In 2011, the Government of Canada and the Bank of Canada extended Canada's inflation-control target through December 31, 2016.
• The Bank of Canada employs three unconventional instruments to achieve its inflation target: a conditional statement on the future path of the policy rate, quantitative easing, and credit easing.
• As a result of inflation-targeting policies, interest rates and inflation decreased, along with the value of the Canadian dollar.
• From 1991 to 2011, the inflation-targeting regime maintained fairly reliable price gains.
• After the Great Recession, the narrow focus of inflation-targeting as a means of ensuring stable economic growth was questioned.

• By 2011, then-Bank of Canada Governor Mark Carney argued for a more flexible inflation-targeting approach, allowing for longer periods—beyond the typical six to eight quarters—to return inflation to 2 percent in specific situations.

• On July 15, 2015, the Bank of Canada announced a reduction of its target overnight rate by 0.25 percentage points, lowering it to 0.5 percent to stimulate an economy that had not meaningfully rebounded from the oil shock-induced decline in the first quarter.
• In the first quarter of 2015, the total CPI inflation was approximately 1 percent, reflecting year-over-year declines in consumer energy prices.
• Core inflation in early 2015 was about 2 percent, with an underlying inflation trend of approximately 1.5 to 1.7 percent.

• Prime Minister Stephen Harper explained that the economy was being negatively impacted by external forces such as global oil prices, the European debt crisis, and China's economic slowdown, which contributed to a fragile global economy.

• By July 2015, the Chinese stock market had lost about US$3 trillion in wealth, leading to panicked stock sell-offs, declines in commodity markets, and adverse effects on resource-dependent countries like Canada.

• The Bank of Canada's primary goal has been to maintain inflation at a moderate level; consequently, interest rates were kept low for nearly seven years, with the key interest rate (overnight rate) at 0.5% since September 2010.
• In mid-2017, inflation remained below the 2% target at 1.6%, mainly due to reductions in energy, food, and automobile costs, while the economy was projected to grow at 2.8% for the year.
• On July 12, 2017, the Bank of Canada announced an increase of the benchmark rate to 0.75%.

• Following the COVID-19 pandemic, critics argued that the Bank of Canada's inflation-targeting policy had unintended consequences, including fueling rising home prices and contributing to wealth inequalities by supporting higher equity valuations.
• In 2020, the Canadian economy's industry composition was measured as a percentage share of Gross Domestic Product (GDP), reflecting the relative economic contribution of each sector.
• The industry with the largest share of GDP was Real estate and rental and leasing, accounting for 13.01%, indicating its significant role in the Canadian economy.
• Manufacturing contributed 10.37% to Canada's GDP, highlighting its importance as a key industrial sector.
• Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction collectively represented 8.21% of GDP, underscoring Canada's substantial natural resource extraction industry.
• The finance and insurance sector accounted for 7.06% of GDP, emphasizing its vital role in the financial stability and services within the country.
• Construction contributed 7.08% to GDP, reflecting ongoing infrastructure development and building activities.
• Health care and social assistance made up 6.63% of GDP, indicating the sector's critical importance to public health and social services.
• Public administration accounted for 6.28% of GDP, representing government and administrative functions at various levels.
• Wholesale trade contributed 5.78% to GDP, serving as a key link in the distribution of goods.
• Retail trade represented 5.60% of GDP, highlighting the significance of consumer spending and retail services.
• Professional, scientific, and technical services contributed 5.54% to GDP, encompassing specialized professional activities.
• Educational services accounted for 5.21% of GDP, reflecting the sector's role in education and academic institutions.
• Transportation and warehousing contributed 4.60% to GDP, supporting logistics and movement of goods and people.
• Information and cultural industries made up 3.00% of GDP, including media, publishing, and cultural sectors.
• Administrative and support, waste management, and remediation services represented 2.46% of GDP, indicating their role in operational support and environmental management.
• Utilities contributed 2.21% to GDP, covering essential services such as electricity, water, and natural gas.
• Accommodation and food services accounted for 2.15% of GDP, reflecting the hospitality and tourism industry.
• Other services (except public administration) comprised 1.89% of GDP, including various personal and repair services.
• Agriculture, forestry, fishing, and hunting collectively represented 1.53% of GDP, emphasizing their role in primary resource industries.
• Arts, entertainment, and recreation contributed 0.77% to GDP, indicating their smaller but culturally significant economic role.
• Management of companies and enterprises accounted for 0.62% of GDP, representing corporate management activities.
• Canada's real estate market is a fundamental component of the national economy, constituting over 13% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by sector in 2020.
• In 2021, housing investment represented 21% of Canada's total national wealth, highlighting its significant economic impact.

• The precise contribution of related sectors such as Construction, Investment and Financial Services, Manufacturing, and Forestry to the broader category of Real Estate, Rental, and Leasing is difficult to quantify due to their complex and interconnected nature within Canada's economy.

• The Bank of Canada has taken measures to influence the mortgage market by increasing its holdings of mortgage bonds, aiming to target 50% of the fixed-rate primary issuances, thereby affecting the availability and cost of mortgage financing.
• The service sector in Canada is extensive and diverse, employing approximately 75% of the Canadian population and accounting for 70% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The retail sector is the largest employer within the service industry, employing nearly 12% of Canadians.
• Retail industry employment is predominantly concentrated in a limited number of chain stores located within shopping malls.
• In recent years, there has been a notable increase in the number of big-box stores, including Walmart (United States), Real Canadian Superstore, and Best Buy (United States).
• The rise of big-box stores has resulted in a reduction of retail jobs and a migration of retail employment to suburban areas.
• Canadian business services are primarily concentrated in major urban centers across the country, notably in large cities.
• The second-largest segment of the service sector is business services, which employs a comparable percentage of the population as retail.
• Business services encompass financial services, real estate, and communications industries, and this segment has experienced rapid growth in recent years.
• The major urban centers where business services are concentrated include Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver, with specific reference to banking activities in Canada.
• The education and health sectors are among Canada's largest service industries, with both sectors primarily under government control or influence.
• The healthcare industry is experiencing rapid growth and is the third-largest sector within Canada’s economy.
• Canada possesses a significant high-tech industry, contributing notably to the national economy.
• The country also has a burgeoning film, television, and entertainment industry that produces content for both domestic and international audiences, as detailed in the Media in Canada.
• Tourism is increasingly vital to the Canadian economy, with the majority of international visitors arriving from the United States.
• Casino gaming is the fastest-growing component of the Canadian tourism industry, generating approximately $5 billion in profits for Canadian governments.
• As of 2001, casino gaming employed around 41,000 Canadians.
• Ford's Oakville Assembly, located in the Greater Toronto Area, is a notable manufacturing facility within Canada's automotive sector.
• Central Canada hosts several auto factories operated by major American and Japanese automakers, highlighting the region's significance in Canada's automotive manufacturing industry.

• The typical development pattern for wealthy nations has historically involved a transition from an economy based on raw material production to one centered on manufacturing, and subsequently to a service-based economy.
• During World War II, in 1944, Canada's manufacturing sector contributed approximately 29% to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• By 2017, the contribution of manufacturing to Canada's GDP had declined to 10.37%, reflecting a significant reduction from its wartime peak.
• Canada has experienced a relatively moderate decline in manufacturing's share of the economy compared to other rich, industrialized nations since the 1960s.

• A 2009 study by Statistics Canada revealed that, although manufacturing's share of GDP decreased from 24.3% in the 1960s to 15.6% in 2005, manufacturing volumes from 1961 to 2005 kept pace with overall GDP growth, indicating productivity improvements.
• Manufacturing in Canada saw a substantial decline during the Great Recession (2007–2009), impacting the sector's output and employment.
• As of 2017, manufacturing accounted for approximately 10% of Canada's GDP, representing a decline of more than 5 percentage points since 2005.
• Central Canada is a hub for automotive manufacturing, hosting branch plants of all major American and Japanese automobile manufacturers.
• Many Canadian-owned parts factories, such as Magna International and Linamar Corporation, operate in Central Canada, supporting the automotive industry's supply chain.
• Canada was the nineteenth-largest steel exporter in the world in 2018.
• In year-to-date 2019 (YTD 2019), Canada exported 1.39 million metric tons of steel, representing a 22 percent decrease from 1.79 million metric tons exported in YTD 2018.
• Canada's steel exports in 2017 accounted for approximately 1.5 percent of all steel exported globally.
• In volume terms, Canada's 2018 steel exports were just over one-tenth the volume of the world's largest exporter, China.
• In value, steel constituted 1.4 percent of Canada's total goods exports in 2018.
• The growth in Canada's steel exports over the decade since 2009 was 29 percent.
• The largest steel producers in Canada in 2018 were ArcelorMittal, Essar Steel Algoma, with ArcelorMittal alone accounting for roughly half of Canadian steel production through its two subsidiaries.
• The top two markets for Canadian steel exports were its NAFTA partners, collectively accounting for 92 percent of exports by volume.
• In YTD 2019, Canada sent 83 percent of its steel exports to the United States.
• The gap between domestic demand and domestic production increased to −2.4 million metric tons in YTD 2019, up from −0.2 million metric tons in YTD 2018.
• In YTD 2019, exports as a share of Canadian steel production decreased to 41.6 percent from 53 percent in YTD 2018.
• In 2017, heavy industry was responsible for 10.2 percent of Canada's greenhouse gas emissions.
• As of 2019, Canada ranks among the largest global producers of various metals, reflecting its significant role in the international mining industry.
• Canada's world rankings in metal production in 2019 are as follows:
• Platinum: 4th largest producer worldwide.
• Gold: 5th largest producer worldwide.
• Nickel: 5th largest producer worldwide.
• Copper: 10th largest producer worldwide.
• Iron ore: 8th largest producer worldwide.
• Titanium: 4th largest producer worldwide.
• Potash: 1st largest producer worldwide.
• Niobium: 2nd largest producer worldwide.
• Molybdenum: 7th largest producer worldwide.
• Cobalt: 7th largest producer worldwide.
• Lithium: 8th largest producer worldwide.
• Zinc: 8th largest producer worldwide.
• In addition to metals, Canada was a major producer of other minerals in 2019:
• Sulfur: 4th largest producer globally.
• Gypsum: 13th largest producer worldwide.
• Antimony: 14th largest producer globally.
• Graphite: 10th largest producer worldwide.
• Salt: 6th largest producer globally.
• In 2018, Canada was the world's second-largest producer of uranium, highlighting its significant contribution to the global nuclear fuel supply.
• Canada benefits from access to inexpensive energy sources due to its geographical advantages.
• This abundance of affordable energy has facilitated the development of key industries within the country.
• Notably, Canada hosts significant aluminum industries located in British Columbia and Quebec, which have grown partly due to the availability of cheap energy.
• Canada ranks among the world's highest per capita consumers of energy, reflecting high energy usage on an individual basis across the population.
• The electricity sector in Canada has been a vital component of the country's economic and political development since the late 19th century.

• The sector is organized along provincial and territorial lines, with most provinces dominated by large, government-owned integrated public utilities responsible for generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity.
• In the last decade, Ontario and Alberta have established electricity markets to promote increased investment and competition within the sector.
• In 2017, the electricity sector contributed approximately 10% to Canada's total national greenhouse gas emissions.
• Canada engaged in substantial electricity trade with the United States, exporting 72 TWh and importing 10 TWh in 2017.

• Hydroelectricity was the dominant source of electric generation in Canada in 2016, accounting for 59% of all electricity produced, positioning Canada as the world's second-largest hydroelectric producer after China.
• Since 1960, large hydroelectric projects, particularly in Quebec, British Columbia, Manitoba, and Newfoundland and Labrador, have significantly expanded Canada's generation capacity.

• Nuclear power is the second-largest source of electricity in Canada, representing 15% of total generation, with several nuclear plants in Ontario producing more than half of the province's electricity and one plant in New Brunswick.
• In 2017, Canada produced 95 TWh of electricity from nuclear power, making it the sixth-largest nuclear electricity producer globally.
• Fossil fuels account for 19% of Canada's electricity, with about half derived from coal (9% of total generation) and the remainder from natural gas and oil.
• Only five provinces utilize coal for electricity generation; Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Nova Scotia rely on coal for nearly half of their electricity needs.
• Other provinces and territories use little or no coal; Alberta and Saskatchewan also heavily depend on natural gas.
• Remote communities, including all of Nunavut and much of the Northwest Territories, primarily generate electricity using diesel generators, which incurs high economic and environmental costs.
• The Canadian federal government has implemented initiatives aimed at reducing reliance on diesel-fired electricity in remote communities.
• Non-hydro renewable energy sources are a rapidly growing segment, constituting approximately 7% of the total electricity generation in 2016.
• Canada has extensive oil and gas resources primarily located in Alberta and the Northern Territories, with additional deposits in British Columbia and Saskatchewan.

• The Athabasca oil sands in Alberta constitute a significant portion of Canada's reserves, making Canada the world's third-largest holder of oil reserves after Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).
• The oil and gas industry accounts for 27% of Canada's total greenhouse gas emissions, representing an 84% increase since 1990, predominantly driven by the development of the oil sands.
• Historically, a key issue in Canadian politics has been the relationship between the oil and energy industry in Western Canada and the industrial center of Southern Ontario.

• Foreign investment in Western Canadian oil projects has contributed to the appreciation of Canada's dollar, which in turn has increased the cost of Ontario's manufacturing exports and reduced their competitiveness, paralleling the decline of manufacturing in the Netherlands.

• The National Energy Policy of the early 1980s aimed to make Canada self-sufficient in oil and to ensure equal supply and pricing across all regions, especially benefiting eastern manufacturing sectors.
• This policy was highly divisive because it mandated Alberta to sell low-priced oil to eastern Canada, which caused regional tensions.
• The policy was abandoned five years after its inception, following a collapse in global oil prices in 1985.
• Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who was elected in 1984, campaigned against the National Energy Policy during the federal election.
• A controversial aspect of the 1988 Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement was a commitment that Canada would never charge the United States more for energy than it charges its own citizens.
• Canada is one of the world's largest suppliers of agricultural products, with a particular emphasis on wheat and other grains.
• The country is a major exporter of agricultural products, primarily to the United States and Asian markets.
• Over the 20th century, the proportion of Canada's population and GDP devoted to agriculture declined significantly, reflecting broader economic and technological shifts.
• In 2015, the agriculture and agri-food manufacturing sector contributed approximately $49.0 billion to Canada's GDP, representing about 2.6% of the total GDP.
• The agriculture sector is responsible for approximately 8.4% of Canada's greenhouse gas emissions, indicating its environmental impact.
• Canada’s agricultural industry receives substantial government subsidies and support, similar to other developed nations.
• The country has actively supported efforts to reduce market-distorting subsidies through the World Trade Organization (WTO).
• In the year 2000, Canada allocated around CDN$4.6 billion to support its agricultural industry.

• Of this support, CDN$2.32 billion was classified under the WTO "green box" designation, which includes subsidies that do not directly influence market prices, such as funding for research or disaster relief.
• All but CDN$848.2 million of the total subsidies were considered to be worth less than 5% of the value of the crops they supported.
• The Canada–Israel Free Trade Agreement, which entered into force on January 1, 1997, is currently undergoing modernization to update and enhance trade relations between the two countries.
• The Canada–Chile Free Trade Agreement came into effect on July 5, 1997, establishing a preferential trade framework between Canada and Chile.
• The Canada–Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement, effective from November 1, 2002, is also undergoing modernization to adapt to evolving trade dynamics.

• The Canada–European Free Trade Association (EFTA) Free Trade Agreement, involving Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, and Liechtenstein, was signed and entered into force on July 1, 2009, facilitating trade between Canada and these EFTA member states.
• The Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement was implemented on August 1, 2009, expanding Canada's trade relations with Peru.

• The Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement was signed on November 21, 2008, and entered into force on August 15, 2011; Canada's ratification was contingent upon Colombia's ratification of the "Agreement Concerning Annual Reports on Human Rights and Free Trade Between Canada and the Republic of Colombia," signed on May 27, 2010.
• The Canada–Jordan Free Trade Agreement was signed on June 28, 2009, and officially entered into force on October 1, 2012, strengthening economic ties with Jordan.
• The Canada–Panama Free Trade Agreement was signed on May 14, 2010, and came into force on April 1, 2013, promoting trade relations with Panama.
• The Canada–South Korea Free Trade Agreement was signed on March 11, 2014, and entered into force on January 1, 2015, marking a significant trade partnership with South Korea.
• The Canada–Ukraine Free Trade Agreement was signed on July 11, 2016, and officially entered into force on August 1, 2017, enhancing economic cooperation with Ukraine.

• The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union was signed on October 30, 2016, and entered into force on September 21, 2017, creating a broad trade framework with the EU.

• The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) was signed on March 8, 2018, and entered into force on December 30, 2018, establishing a major trade bloc in the Asia-Pacific region.

• The Canada–United States–Mexico Agreement (CUSMA), formerly known as NAFTA, was signed on November 30, 2018, and entered into force on July 1, 2020, updating and replacing the previous trade agreement among these three nations.
• The Canada–UK Trade Continuity Agreement was signed on December 9, 2020, and entered into force on April 1, 2021, ensuring continuity of trade relations following Brexit.

sections.section_name: Free-trade agreements no longer in force
openai_summarised_points: • The Canada–U.S. Free Trade Agreement was signed on October 12, 1987, and officially entered into force on January 1, 1989; it was later superseded by the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
• The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) was concluded on October 5, 2015; it was subsequently replaced by the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP).
• The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) came into effect on January 1, 1994; it was later superseded by the United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement (USMCA).
• Canada is actively negotiating bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) with several countries and trade blocs to expand its international trade relations.

• The countries with which Canada is negotiating bilateral FTAs include the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), Guatemala, Nicaragua, El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, India, Japan, Morocco, Singapore, and the Andean Community.
• Among these, FTAs are already in force with Peru and Colombia, members of the Andean Community, indicating existing trade agreements with these nations.
• Canada is also involved in negotiations to establish regional trade blocs, notably the Canada-Central American Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) and the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA).
• The negotiations aim to enhance economic integration and trade relations between Canada and these regional and bilateral partners.

• Canada and the United States maintain a close and significant trading relationship, with both nations experiencing strong job markets; in December 2006, Canada’s unemployment rate reached a 30-year low following 14 consecutive years of employment growth.
• The United States is Canada's largest trading partner, with trade valued at more than $1.7 billion CAD per day in 2005.
• In 2009, 73% of Canada's exports were directed to the United States, and 63% of Canada's imports came from the U.S.
• Trade with Canada accounts for 23% of U.S. exports and 17% of U.S. imports, making it a critical component of U.S. international trade.
• In 2005, U.S.-Canada trade exceeded the total trade the U.S. conducted with all European Union countries combined and was more than twice the trade with all Latin American countries combined.
• The trade crossing the Ambassador Bridge between Michigan and Ontario alone equals all U.S. exports to Japan.
• Canada is the leading export market for 35 of the 50 U.S. states and is the largest foreign energy supplier to the U.S.
• Bilateral trade increased by 52% from 1989, when the U.S.–Canada Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was implemented, to 1994, when the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) replaced it.
• Since 1994, trade has grown by an additional 40%, with NAFTA continuing the FTA's goals of reducing trade barriers and establishing common trade rules.

• NAFTA addresses issues in agriculture, services, energy, financial services, investment, and government procurement, forming the largest trading area globally, encompassing 405 million people across the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.
• The primary component of U.S.–Canada trade is in the commodity sector, notably agriculture, forestry, and energy.
• The U.S. is Canada's largest agricultural export market, purchasing over half of all Canadian food exports.
• Nearly two-thirds of Canada's forest products, including pulp and paper, are exported to the U.S., with 72% of Canada's total newsprint production also exported to the U.S.
• In 2004, U.S.-Canada energy trade was valued at $73.6 billion, making it the largest U.S. energy trading relationship; $66.7 billion of this was exports from Canada.
• The main energy commodities traded are petroleum, natural gas, and electricity; Canada is the U.S.'s largest oil supplier and the fifth-largest energy producer worldwide.
• Canada supplies approximately 16% of U.S. oil imports and 14% of U.S. natural gas consumption.
• The U.S. and Canada have interconnected electricity grids and share hydropower facilities on their western borders.
• Most U.S.-Canada trade flows smoothly, but occasional disputes occur, especially in agriculture and cultural sectors, often resolved through bilateral forums, WTO, or NAFTA dispute mechanisms.
• In May 1999, the U.S. and Canadian governments negotiated an agreement to increase U.S. publishing industry access to the Canadian magazine market.

• Several major fisheries disputes have been resolved, including submitting the Gulf of Maine boundary dispute to the International Court of Justice in 1981, which accepted the October 12, 1984, demarcation ruling.
• A current issue is the softwood lumber dispute, with the U.S. alleging Canada subsidizes its forestry industry unfairly.
• In 1990, the U.S. and Canada signed a bilateral Fisheries Enforcement Agreement to combat illegal fishing and reduce enforcement-related injuries.
• In June 1999, they signed a Pacific Salmon Agreement to settle differences over the 1985 Pacific Salmon Treaty for the following decade.
• An aviation agreement was signed during Bill Clinton’s visit to Canada in February 1995, leading to a significant increase in air traffic between the two countries.
• The U.S. and Canada jointly operate the St. Lawrence Seaway, connecting the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean.
• The U.S. remains Canada’s largest foreign investor; in 2018, U.S. direct investment in Canada totaled $406 billion.

• In the same year, Canadian investment in the U.S. was $595 billion, representing 46% of the overall Canadian direct investment abroad (CDIA) stock, making Canada the second-largest foreign investor in the U.S.
• U.S. investments in Canada are mainly in mining, smelting, petroleum, chemicals, machinery, transportation, and finance sectors.
• Canadian investments in the U.S. are concentrated in manufacturing, wholesale trade, real estate, petroleum, finance, insurance, and other services.
• The section discusses Canada's government bonds, focusing on the yield curve behavior during specific periods.
• An inverted yield curve was observed in Canada during the years 2006–2007 and again in 2019.
• The yield curve data includes various maturities: 30-year, 10-year, 2-year, 1-year, 3-month, and 1-month bonds.
• The 30-year bond refers to long-term government debt instruments with a maturity of 30 years.
• The 10-year bond represents medium-term government debt with a 10-year maturity.
• The 2-year bond indicates short-term government debt with a 2-year maturity.
• The 1-year bond corresponds to debt instruments maturing in one year.
• The 3-month bond pertains to short-term debt with a three-month maturity.
• The 1-month bond signifies very short-term debt instruments maturing in one month.

• The inverted yield curve, which occurs when short-term yields exceed long-term yields, was specifically noted during the periods of 2006–2007 and 2019, signaling potential economic downturns or market expectations of lower future interest rates.
• Canadian government debt, also known as Canada's public debt, represents the liabilities of the government sector within the country.
• For the fiscal year ending 31 March 2020, the total financial liabilities, or gross debt, of the consolidated Canadian general government amounted to $2.434 trillion.
• The consolidated Canadian general government includes federal, provincial, territorial, and local governments combined.
• The total gross debt of $2.434 trillion corresponds to 105.3% of Canada's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• During this period, Canada's GDP was valued at $2.311 trillion.
• Of the total gross debt, $1.146 trillion, or approximately 47%, was attributable to the federal (central) government liabilities.
• The federal government liabilities represented about 49.6% of GDP.
• The remaining liabilities are primarily composed of provincial government liabilities, which constitute most of the other liabilities within the total gross debt.
• Household debt refers to the total amount of money owed by all adults within a household to financial institutions, encompassing both consumer debt and mortgage loans.

• In March 2015, the International Monetary Fund identified Canada's high household debt as one of two vulnerable domestic areas in the country's economy, the other being its overheated housing market.
• As of July 2019, total household credit in Canada was CAD$2.2 trillion, indicating the significant scale of household indebtedness.
• According to Philip Cross of the Fraser Institute, in May 2015, the Canadian household debt-to-income ratio was similar to that of the United States.

• Despite comparable debt-to-income ratios, Canadian lending standards are tighter than those in the United States, a measure implemented to protect against high-risk borrowers taking on unsustainable levels of debt.
• Since 1985, a total of 63,755 mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals involving Canada have been announced, encompassing both inbound and outbound transactions.
• The cumulative value of these deals amounts to approximately US$3.7 billion.
• Nearly 50% of the targets of Canadian companies in outbound deals are based in the United States, indicating a significant cross-border investment relationship.
• Inbound M&A deals into Canada are predominantly from the United States, accounting for 82% of such transactions, highlighting the U.S.'s major role as a source of foreign investment in Canada.
• The largest deal in Canadian history was announced on January 26, 2000, involving a spin-off of Nortel Networks Corp, a Canadian company, with a transaction value of US$59.97 billion.
• The second-largest deal was announced on June 20, 2000, when France’s Vivendi SA acquired Seagram Co Ltd, a Canadian company, for US$40.43 billion.

• The third-largest deal occurred on December 7, 2007, when Rio Tinto Canada Holdings Inc, a Canadian subsidiary of the UK-based Rio Tinto, acquired Alcan Inc, a Canadian company, for US$37.63 billion.
• The fourth-largest deal was announced on June 9, 2016, involving Canadian company Enbridge Inc acquiring Spectra Energy Corp, a U.S. firm, for US$28.29 billion.
• The fifth-largest deal took place on March 12, 2014, where the Enbridge Income Fund acquired Enbridge Inc-Liquids, a Canadian entity, for US$24.79 billion.
• The sixth-largest deal was announced on November 5, 2008, with Canadian shareholders acquiring Cenovus Energy Inc, a Canadian company, for US$20.26 billion.

• The seventh-largest deal was announced on July 23, 2012, involving CNOOC Canada Holding Ltd, a Canadian subsidiary of the Chinese state-owned CNOOC, acquiring Nexen Inc, a Canadian company, for US$19.12 billion.
• The eighth-largest deal was announced on May 15, 2006, when Switzerland’s Xstrata PLC acquired Falconbridge Ltd, a Canadian company, for US$17.40 billion.
• The ninth-largest deal was announced on November 8, 2006, involving Brazil’s Cia Vale do Rio Doce SA acquiring Inco Ltd, a Canadian company, for US$17.15 billion.
• The tenth-largest deal was announced on March 23, 2009, with Suncor Energy Inc acquiring Petro-Canada, a Canadian company, for US$15.58 billion.
• The eleventh-largest deal was announced on July 29, 2008, involving Canadian company Teck Cominco Ltd acquiring Fording Canadian Coal Trust, for US$13.60 billion.

• The table presents key economic indicators for Canada from 1980 to 2021, with IMF staff estimates for 2022 to 2027, highlighting trends in GDP, per capita income, growth rates, inflation, unemployment, and government debt.

• In 1980, Canada's GDP measured 288.7 billion US dollars in PPP terms, with a per capita GDP of 11,798.2 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 276.1 billion US dollars, and per capita nominal GDP was 11,281.4 US dollars.
• The GDP growth rate fluctuated over the years, with notable increases such as 5.9% in 1984 and 4.7% in 1985, and declines like -3.2% in 1982 and -2.9% in 2009.

• Inflation rates varied, with values below 5% marked in green; for example, in 1983 (5.8%) and 1984 (4.3%), while in 1981 and 1982, inflation was significantly higher at 12.5% and 10.8%, respectively.
• Unemployment rates ranged from 7.5% in 1980 to a peak of 12.0% in 1983, with fluctuations throughout the period, reaching as low as 5.8% in 2019.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP increased from 44.6% in 1980 to a high of 97.5% in 1994, then fluctuated, reaching 112.9% in 2021 before decreasing to 98.7% projected for 2023.
• The nominal GDP consistently increased over the decades, from 276.1 billion US dollars in 1980 to an estimated 2,353.9 billion US dollars in 2023.
• Real GDP growth was relatively modest in the early 2000s, with rates around 1.8% to 3.2%, but experienced a notable decline in 2009 (-2.9%) due to the global financial crisis.
• The period from 2010 onward shows steady growth, with real GDP growth rates mostly between 1.5% and 3.3%, and inflation generally remaining below 5%, often in the 1-3% range.

• In 2020, Canada experienced a significant contraction with a -5.2% real GDP decline, coinciding with the COVID-19 pandemic, and unemployment rose to 9.6%, while government debt surged to 117.8% of GDP.

• The IMF estimates project a gradual recovery with real GDP growth rates around 1.5% to 2.3% from 2024 to 2027, and inflation rates remaining mostly below 5%, with some years experiencing slightly higher inflation.
• Per capita GDP in nominal terms increased from approximately 11,281.4 US dollars in 1980 to an estimated 66,221.6 US dollars in 2027, reflecting overall economic growth and population increases.
• The data indicates a general trend of economic expansion, with periods of recession and recovery, and fluctuations in inflation, unemployment, and government debt levels over the decades.
• The table underscores Canada's economic resilience and growth trajectory, with consistent increases in GDP and per capita income, despite periodic economic downturns and global economic challenges.

• As of April 2025, the unemployment rate across Canadian provinces varies, with Alberta experiencing a rate of 7.1%, while Saskatchewan has the lowest at 4.3%, indicating regional disparities in employment conditions.
• The unemployment rate in Newfoundland and Labrador is notably higher at 9.6%, suggesting a comparatively weaker labor market in that province.
• British Columbia's unemployment rate stands at 6.2%, and Ontario's is slightly higher at 7.8%, reflecting differing economic dynamics within these major provinces.
• Manitoba reports an unemployment rate of 5.3%, whereas Quebec has a rate of 6.0%, both indicating relatively lower unemployment levels compared to some eastern provinces.
• The national unemployment rate in Canada is 6.9%, serving as an aggregate indicator of the country's overall labor market health.

• The participation rate, which measures the percentage of the working-age population actively engaged in the labor force, varies by province, with Alberta at 68.5%, and Newfoundland and Labrador at 58.3%, highlighting differences in labor engagement.
• British Columbia's participation rate is 65.1%, Ontario's is 65.0%, and Quebec's is 65.3%, indicating relatively stable labor force engagement in these regions.
• Manitoba's participation rate is 66.4%, Saskatchewan's is 66.8%, and Prince Edward Island's is 65.9%, all reflecting high levels of labor force participation.

• The total employment across Canada as of April 2025 is approximately 20,969,300 individuals, with Ontario having the largest employment figure at 8,195,200, emphasizing its role as a major employment hub.
• Alberta's employment stands at 2,565,800, British Columbia's at 2,950,900, and Quebec's at 4,645,600, illustrating the distribution of employment across key provinces.
• Manitoba employs about 736,000 people, New Brunswick 400,400, Nova Scotia 516,400, Prince Edward Island 94,300, and Newfoundland and Labrador 248,100, reflecting regional employment sizes.
• In 2021, Canada’s export trade was valued at US$503.4 billion, measured in US dollars.
• This export value represents a 19.5% increase since 2017.
• From 2020 to 2021, Canadian exports increased by 29.1%.
• The United States is Canada's primary trading partner, accounting for US$380.4 billion in exports, which constitutes 75.6% of total Canadian exports in 2021.
• China is the second-largest export partner, with exports valued at US$23 billion, representing 4.6% of total exports.
• The United Kingdom's exports totaled US$12.9 billion, making up 2.6% of the total.
• Japan imported US$11.5 billion worth of Canadian goods, accounting for 2.3%.
• Mexico's exports amounted to US$6.5 billion, representing 1.3%.
• Germany imported US$5.5 billion worth of Canadian goods, or 1.1%.
• South Korea's exports to Canada were valued at US$4.5 billion, or 0.9%.
• The Netherlands accounted for US$3.8 billion in exports, or 0.8%.
• France's exports totaled US$3.2 billion, representing 0.6%.
• Belgium imported US$3.0 billion worth of Canadian goods, also 0.6%.
• Hong Kong's exports were valued at US$2.8 billion, constituting 0.6%.
• Norway's exports to Canada amounted to US$2.5 billion, or 0.5%.
• Switzerland imported US$1.6 billion worth of Canadian products, or 0.5%.
• India’s exports to Canada were US$2.35 billion, representing 0.5%.
• Italy's exports totaled US$2.1 billion, accounting for 0.4%.
• In 2017, Canada's import trade was measured in US dollars, reflecting the total value of goods imported into the country from various international partners.
• The United States was Canada's largest import partner, with imports valued at $222.0 billion, accounting for 51.3% of total imports.
• China ranked as the second-largest import partner, with imports valued at $54.7 billion, representing 12.7% of total imports.
• Mexico was the third-largest source of imports, with a total of $27.4 billion, making up 6.3% of the import share.
• Germany contributed $13.8 billion worth of imports to Canada, constituting 3.2% of the total import value.
• Japan's imports to Canada were valued at $13.5 billion, representing 3.1% of the total.
• The United Kingdom supplied goods worth $6.9 billion, which is 1.6% of Canada's total imports.
• South Korea's import value was $6.7 billion, accounting for 1.5% of the total.
• Italy contributed $6.3 billion in imports, also representing 1.5% of the total import value.
• France's imports to Canada totaled $4.8 billion, making up 1.1% of the overall import trade.
• Vietnam supplied goods worth $3.9 billion, constituting 0.9% of Canada's total imports.
